title: Roth Score for Hypoxia Screening
description: Screens for hypoxia in dyspneic patients using a simple verbal counting test. The Roth Score evaluates respiratory distress by measuring how high a patient can count from 1 to 30 in a single breath and how long it takes. This tool was developed for telemedicine applications and can help risk-stratify dyspnea severity in terms of hypoxia, though it does not replace pulse oximetry or comprehensive clinical evaluation.

parameters.name: max_number_reached
parameters.description: Maximum number reached when counting from 1 to 30 in a single breath

parameters.name: total_seconds_counted
parameters.description: Total seconds taken to count (regardless of final number reached)

result.name: roth_score_assessment
result.description: Roth Score assessment for hypoxia screening based on counting performance

ranges.interpretation: Patient shows severe respiratory distress with very limited counting ability. High risk for significant hypoxia (O2 sat likely <90%). Immediate pulse oximetry measurement and oxygen assessment required. Consider emergency respiratory support and further evaluation for underlying respiratory pathology. This finding suggests severe dyspnea that warrants urgent clinical intervention.

Patient demonstrates moderate respiratory distress with impaired counting performance. Increased risk for hypoxia (O2 sat potentially <95%). Pulse oximetry measurement recommended to confirm oxygen saturation status. Consider oxygen supplementation if clinically indicated and evaluate for underlying respiratory conditions. Monitor closely for worsening respiratory status.

Patient shows mild respiratory compromise with some counting difficulty. Lower risk for severe hypoxia but clinical correlation recommended. Pulse oximetry should be performed to confirm oxygen saturation. Consider underlying respiratory conditions and continue monitoring. May benefit from supportive care and further assessment based on clinical presentation.

Patient demonstrates good respiratory reserve with normal counting ability. Low risk for significant hypoxia. While pulse oximetry remains the gold standard for oxygen assessment, this finding suggests adequate respiratory function. Continue routine monitoring and evaluate other clinical factors contributing to dyspnea symptoms if present.

references: Chorin E, Padegimas A, Havakuk O, Birati EY, Shacham Y, Milman A, Flint N, Konigstein M, Nevzorov R, Moshe Y, Margolis G, Alcalai R, Topilsky Y. Assessment of Respiratory Distress by the Roth Score. Clin Cardiol. 2016 Nov;39(11):636-639. doi: 10.1002/clc.22570.

García-Villafranca M, Escolano-Casado G, González-Del Castillo J, Martín-Sánchez FJ. The use of the Roth score in emergency department for patients with acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Am J Emerg Med. 2024 Dec;86:164-165. doi: 10.1016/j.ajem.2024.09.025.
formula: Roth Score Assessment = Combination of (1) Maximum number reached counting 1-30 in single breath AND (2) Total seconds taken to count. Thresholds: High risk if max <7 numbers OR <5 seconds; Moderate risk if max 7-9 numbers OR 5-7 seconds; Low risk if max ≥10 numbers AND ≥7 seconds
notes: Roth Score screens for hypoxia in dyspneic patients using verbal counting test
Patient takes deep breath and counts 1-30 as fast as possible without stopping
Record both maximum number reached and total seconds elapsed
Maximum <10 numbers: 91% sensitive for O2 sat <95%
Maximum <7 numbers: 87% sensitive for O2 sat <90%
Total time <7 seconds: 83% sensitive for O2 sat <95%
Total time <5 seconds: 82% sensitive for O2 sat <90%
Developed for telemedicine and remote patient assessment
Particularly useful during pandemic screening situations
Does NOT replace pulse oximetry or comprehensive clinical evaluation
Based on original study of only 93 patients - limited validation
Not validated in all languages (Spanish version showed poor validity)
Tool provides gross screening for hypoxia only
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment
May be helpful when pulse oximetry unavailable
Consider patient's baseline respiratory function and comorbidities
False positives may occur in patients with vocal cord issues
False negatives possible in compensated respiratory conditions
Most useful for detecting moderate to severe respiratory distress
Results should prompt formal oxygen saturation measurement
